awd_titl_txt: Thermal conductivity of Deep Earth's materials studied by fast pulsed laser techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
Knowledge of thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity of the Earth's minerals under extreme conditions is important for understanding the physical and chemical processes and their evolution in the Earth. The rate of the heat transport through the mantle is crucial for the existence and stability of the Earth's magnetic field. The temperature distribution inside the Earth's mantle depends on the rate of heat transfer by convection, conduction, and radiation. An understanding of these processes requires knowledge of the thermal conductivity as a function of pressure and temperature. 

Thermal conductivity of materials in Earth and planetary interiors is one of the key parameters controlling the thermal history of the core and mantle and their dynamics. These are related to the processes of planetary accretion and differentiation, the time evolution of mantle and core temperatures, and the generation of the Earth's magnetic field. In this project, it is proposed to determine the thermal conductivity of the Earth's key minerals under high P-T conditions by using pump-probe pulsed laser techniques. To determine the lattice thermal conductivity, the heat fluxes across the sample and their time history using time- and spatially resolved spectroradiometry and/or time-domain thermoreflectance will be measured. These measurements will be applied to lower mantle minerals and also Fe and Fe-rich alloys. To infer the radiative thermal conductivity, the optical spectra of these mantle minerals in the ultraviolet-to-infrared spectral range at high P-T conditions (up to 150 GPa and 6000 K) will be studied. For in situ high-temperature measurements of the optical properties, broad band optical spectroscopy systems in visible and infrared spectral ranges will be employed which use supercontinuum and nonlinearly mixed pulsed laser sources in combination with time-resolved multichannel detectors (streak camera, intensified CCD, and array MCT detector). These techniques will be applied to study lower mantle minerals, silicate melts, and planetary ices. These experimental data will give a direct estimate of the radiative and conduction parts of the thermal conductivity of deep Earth materials at the relevant P-T conditions. Knowledge of the depth-dependent thermal conductivity of the Earth's mantle will complement recent advances in mantle convection modeling, where a range of possible dynamic structures are predicted depending on the assumed thermal conductivity. Thus, the PI's work will provide a crucial test of these models and our current understanding of the Earth's interior.

por.por_cntn:
The thermal history of the core and mantle and their dynamics is one of the most fundamental topics in geophysics. It is related to the processes of planetary accretion and differentiation, the time evolution of mantle and core temperatures, and the generation of Earth’s magnetic field. The thermal conductivity of materials in the Earth’s and planetary interiors is the key to understanding these phenomena.

In this project, we performed the direct measurements of thermal conductivity of deep Earth’s materials using our pulsed laser techniques applied to the samples in a laser heated diamond anvil cell, which generate the relevant pressure-temperature (P-T) conditions. These results can be utilized in model calculations of the thermal processes in the Earth, thus providing a crucial test of these models and our current understanding of the Earth’s interior.

We determined the conductive (through atomic vibrations and electronic transport) and radiative (through light emission) parts of thermal conductivity in separate experiments. This is essential for minerals for which both these mechanisms are viable at extreme P-T conditions. To determine the heat conductance, we applied the Transient Heating technique (Fig. 1), which applies a short laser heating pulse to the one side of the continuously laser preheated sample and measures  the temperature histories from both sides of the sample using time- and spatially- resolved spectroradiometry, thus inferring the time dependent heat flux across the sample [1]. To infer the radiative thermal conductivity, we measured the optical spectra of the mantle minerals using the Broad Band Optical Spectroscopy technique (Fig. 2), which utilizes a very bright white pulsed laser and time-resolved spectral data acquisition [2].

Our measurements of thermal conductivity of Fe to 130 GPa and 3300 K [1] (Fig. 1) yielded values near the low end of previous estimates, at 18–44 W/m/K for thermal conductivity of Fe in the outer Earth’s core suggesting an old inner core and that the geodynamo will persist for a long time into the future.

Our measurements of radiative conductivity of the lower mantle minerals (bridgmanite, ferropericlase, and postperovskite [3]) and their assemblages (Fig. 2) showed very low values at the P-T conditions at the base of the mantle near the core-mantle boundary (CMB) revealing that radiative heat transport is essentially blocked due to an increased optical absorption in the hot lower mantle. This suggests a reduced CMB heat flow, which is nevertheless sufficient to drive the present-day geodynamo, but implies a very old inner core.  

Our optical spectroscopy measurements at extreme P-T conditions also demonstrated capabilities of this technique in probing and identifying the spin transitions of Fe, thus enabling future determination of the spin state of Earth’s mantle [4]. Moreover, these measurements can probe ionization phenomena at extreme P-T conditions relevant to other planets, which have been demonstrated in our works on examples of noble gases and simple molecules (H2, N2, CH4) [5, 6] (Fig. 3).  

The technical developments of this work enabled measurement of the lattice and radiative thermal conductivity of the deep Earth’s materials, knowledge of which are important for understanding of the Earth thermal history and dynamics. A number of postdoctoral associates working on the projects have been trained in novel ultrafast laser spectroscopy techniques and their applications to geo- planetary and material sciences.

1. Zuzana Konôpková, R. Stewart McWilliams, Natalia Gómez-Pérez, Alexander F. Goncharov (2016). Direct measurement of thermal conductivity in solid iron at planetary core conditions.  Nature. 534, 99; DOI: 10.1038/nature18009

2. Sergey S. Lobanov, Nicholas Holtgrewe, Alexander F. Goncharov (2016). Reduced radiative conductivity of low spin FeO6-octahedra in FeCO3 at high pressure and temperature.  EPSL 449, 20; DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.epsl.2016.05.028

3. Sergey S. Lobanov, Nicholas Holtgrewe, Jung-Fu Lin, Alexander F. Goncharov (2017). Radiative conductivity and abundance of post-perovskite in the lowermost mantle. EPSL 479, 43; doi.org/10.1016/j.epsl.2017.09.016

4. Sergey S. Lobanov, Han Hsu, Jung-Fu Lin, Takashi Yoshino, Alexander F. Goncharov (2017). Optical signatures of low spin Fe3+ in NAL at high pressure.  Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth. 122, 3245. DOI: 10.1002/2017JB014134

5. McWilliams, R. S., D. A. Dalton, M. F. Mahmood, A. F. Goncharov (2016). Optical Properties of Fluid Hydrogen at the Transition to a Conducting State. Phys. Rev. Lett. 116, 255501. doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.255501

6. Shuqing Jiang, Nicholas Holtgrewe, Sergey S. Lobanov , Fuhai Su, Mohammad F. Mahmood, R. Stewart McWilliams, & Alexander F. Goncharov (2018). Metallization and molecular dissociation of dense fluid nitrogen.  NATURE COMMUNICATIONS 9, 2624. DOI: 10.1038/s41467-018-05011-z
